results.title: Kevin Costner Alleges Estranged Wife Uses Child Support to Fund Her Plastic Surgery
results.body:
AceShowbiz - Kevin Costner is said to have alleged his estranged wife Christine Baumgartner demands nearly $250,000 in child support payments for plastic surgery. In court documents, the "Yellowstone" actor, 68, reportedly claimed his forensic accountant had found the 49-year-old handbag designer - who filed for divorce in May - spends more than $100,000 in cosmetic surgery procedures which he apparently says is the real reason she is asking for the money.

The papers obtained by Page Six amid the couple's increasingly bitter divorce fight also showed Christine has spent thousands of dollars on shopping, construction loans, attorneys' fees and other expenses that have "nothing" to do with her children.

Christine, who has children Cayden Wyatt, 16, Hayes Logan, 14, and Grace Avery, 13, with Kevin, previously argued the $248,000 a month she is requesting is "less than the amount needed to maintain the children in their accustomed lifestyle."

She also claimed she has "no income" of her own and has been a "stay-at-home" mum since 2007 when her oldest child was born. But Kevin is said to have stated in the new court documents that he believes $51,940 a month, which is what he's currently paying, is a "reasonable" amount.

Christine filed for divorce after 18 years of marriage, citing "irreconcilable differences," and the exes' finances have so far been the biggest point of contention.

Kevin's personal finances were recently laid bare as part of the split fight after the actor appealed for them to be kept private.

Christine detailed in a court filing how much the actor made and spent last year in an effort to protest how much she will receive in spousal support. Papers showed Kevin and his family splurged nearly $12 million on expenses in the last 12 months.

Kevin had argued in court documents also obtained by Page Six he did not want his financial information to be made public out of fear that "irreparable harm" will be done to him by fraudsters.

Papers showed he earned a total of $19,517,064.32 before taxes due to income he accrued from TV and film projects, rentals and social security. He and his family spent $11,921,543.89 in expenses last year, leaving Kevin with a 2022 net income of just over $7.5 million.

A huge slice of Kevin's spending went on his three homes, including a property in Santa Barbara, California, another in Aspen, Colorado, and a third called the "Beach House".

Christine is seeking $248,000 per month from Kevin to help raise their three children. Court papers revealed she wants a small fortune to maintain the lifestyles of her and Kevin's kids.

She also wants Kevin to pay for their kids' private-school tuition, extracurricular activities, sports and health care expenses, according to the court documents.

results.title: F1 GP Austria 2023: TV, horarios y dónde ver la carrera de Red Bull Ring en directo online
results.body:
Conoce la fecha, hora, dónde ver en directo por televisión y cómo seguir en vivo online el GP de Austria 2023 de Fórmula 1 en Red Bull Ring, décima cita de la temporada.

El Mundial de Fórmula 1 para una semana tras el GP de Canadá para llegar el fin de semana 1 y 2 de julio al GP de Austria. El circuito de Red Bull Ring en Spielberg será testigo del segundo esprint de lo que va de temporada después del disputado en el GP de Azerbaiyán.

El pasado GP de Canadá en Montreal tuvo de nuevo como ganador a Max Verstappen, con Alonso y Hamilton en el podio. Pero, a diferencia de grandes premios anteriores, se pudo ver cómo Aston Martin y Mercedes estaban un paso más cerca de Red Bull y recortaron diferencias durante la carrera en el Gilles Villeneuve. Aún así, el neerlandés se mantiene líder destacado de la general con 195 puntos por los 126 de Sergio Pérez, segundo y los 117 de Fernando Alonso, tercero.

El Mundial de Fórmula 1 2023 se podrá seguir por televisión en DAZN F1 en España. En Argentina, Colombia, Chile y Perú retransmitirán la competición a través de Star + y ESPN. Y en México, el canal será Fox Sports. En Estados Unidos se podrá ver a través de ESPN.

Además, en AS.com podrá seguir en vivo y en directo tanto los entrenamientos libres, como la clasificación del sábado y la carrera del domingo. Y además encontrarás la mejor información del Mundial de F1 y todas las reacciones de los protagonistas, crónicas y análisis...

results.title: Kieran Shannon: Dr Martin McIntyre aiming to curb the most common ailment in GAA - The hamstring injury
results.body:
Dr Martin McIntyre is one of those hidden figures and servants behind one of the most formidable setups in Irish sport for the past decade.

He would have been the first team medic to arrive on the scene of Tom Parson's horrific leg injury sustained against Galway five years ago and other such emergency zones but even then he'd have been unobtrusive, in keeping with the Belmullet man's unassuming personal nature.

Last month though in London at the FIFA Isokinetic Pursuit of Excellence conference, as well as at the appropriately-titled Cutting Edge conference in the University of Limerick, McIntyre briefly took centre stage to launch a process and device that seriously detects and reduces the most common injury in Gaelic and professional football.

"The moment it came to a head for me was in 2017 when we lost two players in the All Ireland semi-final replay [against Kerry through hamstring injuries and had just two weeks to get them ready for the final," he explains. "They'd each suffered grade-one tears, which are basically four-week injuries so you were in a race against time."

They'd win that race, thanks to the diligence and efforts of the likes of McIntyre and Dr Seán Moffatt and other selfless members of that medical support team. In the dressing room straight after the Kerry replay a phonecall was put in securing spots in a cryotherapy chamber for that evening.

On the bus back to Mayo both players were hooked up to a Game Ready therapy machine in the back-row seats. Then for the next week they received around-the-clock rehab from the likes of McIntyre so they could not just play but perform, resulting in the pair of them and their teammates bringing Dublin to the brink in what was possibly the best All Ireland final ever.

"Hamstring injuries have increased significantly over the last 10, 15 years, even for all the advancements in preparation and technology. And I could see that working with teams. You were kind of ahead of the research that way, seeing the trends within teams, and then the research confirmed it."

As part of his doctorate from his alma mater Liverpool John Moores University, McIntyre found that the amount of hamstring injuries in Gaelic had doubled over the decade.

In a bad season you could lose 10 players to hamstrings; in a good year you'll still lose about three for some time. So to help reduce and cure such injuries, he has invented a device, designed by the sports engineering group in Sheffield Hallam University. It's called the H-RIG, as in a hamstring rig. Last month at both the conferences in Limerick and London, a video was played on a loop of Aidan O'Shea illustrating his running motion and how the device and system works.

"Seventy percent of hamstrings occur when you run," explains McIntyre, who happened to coach O'Shea with both Breaffy and Mayo a few years back.

"It's either just prior to touchdown, which we call late swing, or on touchdown, which we call early stance. And the reason it occurs in those positions is because that is when they are under most pressure; you are required to tolerate anything between 3,000 to 4,000 newtons of force. So we decided if this is where players are getting injured, why not test them in late swing or early stance to see how strong their hamstrings are? Can they tolerate the forces required there?

"So we put the athlete like an Aidan into our device where he sits into the frame we've designed in a position where his knee is extended at a 150 degrees angle and his contralateral (non-tested) limb into 20 degrees of extension. His ankle or heel is put into a foot-hook which has a force transductor or a load-cell that's linked to an iPad and software system and that measures the amount of force that's transmitting through the hook."

All in all McIntyre's isometric hamstring assessment device costs just shy of €20,000 but already a couple of GAA counties have viewed it as an investment rather than a cost while leading football clubs from Spain, Portugal, Brazil and the UK have followed up from the FIFA conference with queries and orders. The reason is obvious.

It will reduce the number of hamstring injuries during the playing season and ensure greater player availability for training and games. Players can identify and address any underlying deficits they have which would make them more susceptible to injury. S&C coaches know where to strengthen them up. A medical team can give an accurate prognosis of how long rehabilitation will take, if a player is good to go back or if they're vulnerable to a recurrence of the hamstring injury.

McIntyre at some stage or another has worn all those hats. He was a decent athlete himself; at 17 he went on trial to Glasgow Celtic and after he returned from John Moores with a degree in sports science, back when no such course existed in this country, he played a season in the League of Ireland with Limerick City.

By then his day job was in Tralee IT, running their new human performance laboratory. Soon, on top of coaching the Sigerson team for a stint, he was brought into the Kerry senior setup. Páidí Ó Sé wouldn't have had a reputation for being particularly scientific but McIntyre's experience of the man was that he hugely receptive to whatever could improve his players and team.

"I remember the first day going into training and getting this massive clap in the back. Páidí loved to give the old warm clap in the back! He knew I was from Mayo but more than that he knew I was a Gaeltacht man as well, being from Belmullet, so you had that connection straightaway. And as long as he found you were genuine and helping his players he was very welcoming and supportive of all you did."

McIntyre in his six years with Kerry would liaise closely with Páidí and Jack O'Connor, team trainers like John O'Keeffe and then his Tralee IT work colleague Pat Flanagan but particularly so players such as Seamus Moynihan.

During James Horan's tenure Mayo would take pride in their Ali-like mantra and application of doing the work away from the lights but for McIntyre it was the prototype of what they should aspire to.

"He was the type of guy that if you weren't pushing him he wouldn't come to you for advice. He needed, wanted to be pushed. So you'd have to push him physically to make sure he could get back on the pitch and that he knew he had the work done and hadn't any weakness where he might have had before."

McIntyre was there for the All Ireland wins of 2000, 2004 and 2006 but the latter two in particular were bittersweet on account of the identity of their opponents in the final.

"I remember ringing my mum and dad in the lead-up to those finals and them being so optimistic because of the vibes in the county and how well the team had played to get there. But I was privy to how the Kerry lads were flying in training going into those games and in the back of my mind I was thinking, 'God, Mum and Dad, I think all your hopes will be crushed because it's going to take something extremely special to beat this Kerry team."

After the last of those All Irelands he finished up with Kerry and in Tralee IT, giving up the security of a permanent job there to upskill and go back to college, this time in Sheffield to study sports medicine. He was only finishing it up and returning home when he got a call from Fergal O'Donnell in Roscommon and subsequently played a part in that county's 2007 All Ireland minor win and 2010 Connacht senior title success.

By 2013 he had linked up with his native county, helping make it one of the most respected medical and backroom teams on the scene. Upon Horan's return in 2019 McIntyre was promoted and entrusted to being the team's defacto high performance co-ordinator as well as a selector, a role he fulfilled up to the 2020 All Ireland final after which he reluctantly stepped down to complete his doctorate.

His knowledge and experience of all those fields means he has a particular unique and authoritative perspective on the splurge of hamstring injuries in his sport, prompting an innovation and intervention like the H-RIG.

"One of the biggest factors for me is that players are getting quicker. If you look at the GPS readings, your top speeds 10 years ago would have been about 35km per hour. Now your top players, say a Tommy Conroy, he would be hitting over 36 and sometimes 37km per hour. They're more conditioned, they're stronger, and the pitches are better. But that's putting a huge amount of load on your hamstrings.

"And as well as that the game is evolving. At the conference in UL last month there were a number of sports medicine practitioners from professional football and spoke of how with more teams now sitting back and playing on the counter-attack, there's more accelerations and decelerations, which means there's more load on your hamstrings. That in turn increases the injury risk.

"And in Gaelic football we can see with the way the game is evolving, you're seeing teams being more defensive and going maybe three minutes without touching the ball before suddenly you see five or six players counter-attacking and getting to top speed very quickly."

Is there a style of play so that is more hamstring-friendly?

"In an ideal world you'd find a balance. If you're trying to beat a blanket, you might not have players hitting top speeds that often; there's a lot of play round the edges, looking for an opportunity to break through the line. There isn't as much accelerations or decelerations, though you might attempt to hit top speed eventually during a phase of play."

As the high performance co-ordinator with Mayo and any role he has had as a sports scientist and medic, liaising with various other coaches and support providers in the setup, he has put a primacy on data.

"You're almost taking the emotion out of it. You need to be cold and objective in terms of what is your plan, what should be the performance plans of each player, what in the setup do we need to improve in?"

And yet he knows emotion drives so much of this too. Multiple members of the Mayo setup still recall at one team camp a week out from an All Ireland semi-final, Horan asked each member of the circle to speak about the cause they were serving.

McIntyre quietly but powerfully spoke about the morning of a Connacht final in Castlebar, he got in a 6am run on a remote beach and on his drive back to shower at home he came across a man in his mid-sixties, dressed in his Sunday mass shoes and pants, wearing a Mayo jersey.

"It would have been seven o'clock in the morning. He'd have had to walk for two hours to even get into Belmullet town to get a lift for Castlebar. He was a man that had seen many a game, I would say. Just as the amount of preparation the players and backroom members put in, that man heading off on his journey to see our team was putting in his preparation too. This meant as much to him as any of us."

As someone who has gone on some journey himself, from Belmullet to Liverpool, to better his field and Mayo, McIntyre could relate.

results.title: Change in number of shares and votes in Better Collective A/S - Analysguiden
results.body:
During June, the number of shares and votes in Better Collective A/S has increased. As of June 30, 2023, the number of shares and votes in Better Collective A/S amounts to 55,176,836 following an issue of 22,167 new ordinary shares.

Regulatory release no. 29/2023

Reference is made to regulatory release no. 26: "Exercise of warrants in Better Collective A/S; Board of Directors issues 22,167 new ordinary shares" released on June 9, 2023.

With a vision to become the Leading Digital Sports Media Group, Better Collective owns and operates international, as well as local, sports communities and media that aim to make sports entertainment sustainably engaging and fun. Via its online media, the Group provides prime quality content, data insights, betting tips and educational tools for enthusiastic sports fans all over the world. Headquartered in Copenhagen, Denmark, and listed on Nasdaq Stockholm (BETCO), Better Collective's portfolio includes; Action Network, VegasInsider.com, HLTV.org, FUTBIN.com, and bettingexpert.com. To learn more about Better Collective please visit bettercollective.com

Attachments

results.title: The untold stories of Andy Murray's epic 2013 Wimbledon glory - by those closest to him
results.body:
A decade ago, Murray ended Britain's 77-year wait for a men's champion. This is his story told by those who built him

As we approach the tenth anniversary of Andy Murray's first Wimbledon title, Simon Briggs asked members of his family and entourage to recall their memories of a tumultuous fortnight

Judy Murray (mother): I'd seen how devastated Andy was when he lost the final to Roger Federer the year before. I was just praying that everything went right with his body and that he could cope with all the pressure and distraction that comes with Wimbledon.

Jez Green (fitness trainer): Andy knew how good he was. In the previous year's final, he had been a set and a break up on Roger, then the roof closed and Roger started doing Roger things. Andy got his revenge in the Olympic final, winning in straight sets. But in 2013 there was a question mark about his back, which had locked up during the Italian Open six weeks earlier. In the end, we decided to skip the French Open, thinking "What's the point, when we could have an extra month training on the grass?" It was partly physical and partly strategic. But I think Andy might have needed a cortisone shot to deal with that back.

Mark Bender (physio): I got called in by my colleague Andy Ireland in May 2013. Andy had pulled out of the French Open and he was in a bad way. MRI scans showed that one joint in his vertebrae was really badly damaged. He had pain referring down his leg. And in a way, I think it worked in his favour. Having felt that he couldn't get through five-set matches in Paris, he began to improve physically, and he was really thrilled to win Queen's. He began to think, "Gosh, I've got nothing to lose here." It took a bit of pressure off him.

Friday, June 21: The Wimbledon draw throws up Benjamin Becker (no relation to Boris) as Murray's first-round opponent. On paper, he is expected to play Rafael Nadal in the semi-finals.

Judy: I'd been around long enough never to look beyond the first round. In the media, people would be plotting out the route to the final as soon as the draw comes out, but I'd think "For goodness sakes, one match at a time."

Marion Bartoli (women's champion in 2013): On the Sunday before the tournament started it was raining and we were the last two players still practising at Aorangi Park before they closed the courts. Andy said to me later, "I knew we would go far, both of us, because we were the only ones standing there."

Judy: During matches, I'd try to sit next to Leon on the end seat. Somebody I have known forever, somebody who knows I don't want to be spoken to during a match. No chit-chat!

Leon Smith (childhood coach and Davis Cup captain): In a support box like that, you don't want everyone going mad, because it would look ridiculous. We had a nice balance: Ivan [Lendl] being deadpan, Matt [Little, Murray's fitness trainer] being high energy, Kim [Murray's wife] who knows exactly what Andy needs. You have to be locked in for the whole match, because you don't want Andy to look up and see someone having a chat or eating a Haribo.

Jamie Murray (brother and future doubles world No 1): I wasn't in the box during that tournament. It's just not that comfortable. You have to be aware of how you're reacting because all that stuff gets picked up by him. I'm happier watching on TV.

Bender: Ivan is a man of few words, someone who can say chapters and chapters with a single stare. He was the rock of the team, pulling all the different people together. I found it amazing that, after practices or matches, Ivan would just say "Well done, Andy", pick up his golf clubs and head out to the course. But then you could see that, when Ivan said something as simple as "You're moving well on court", Andy's whole body-language would lift.

Ivan Lendl (coach): I don't think about 2013 that much. When I do, I just remember how well Andy played. You know me. I don't think backwards or forwards.

Rob Stewart (fixer): I lived 15 minutes away from Andy and I used to drive him up the A3 from Oxshott to the All England Club every morning in this beat-up old Volkswagen Polo. We would chat about something and anything, football or politics - but never tennis. That Polo was always the shabbiest car in the whole of the Aorangi car-park, which I thought was very Andy. If you're driving to Wimbledon every day, do you want to be sat there in a car that's garnering attention?

Bender: Judy would bring her mum's shortbread along in an old-school metal tin. It would get passed around the player's box, as well as Andy's friends and family. When it was passed to you, you felt like you were taking holy communion. And once he had got through the first couple of rounds, it became an essential part of the experience. It was bloody beautiful shortbread. The sugar level was pretty high, but we needed that boost to get through.

Monday, June 3: After defeating Becker, Lu Yen-hsun, Tommy Robredo and Mikhail Youzhny all in straight sets, Murray faces the dangerous Spaniard Fernando Verdasco in the quarter-finals.

Judy: It was funny when Andy drew Fernando Verdasco in the quarters because it cast my mind back to Andy's first Challenger tournament, when he was just a skinny 16-year-old kid with shorts too big for him. It was in Segovia, near Madrid, and I remember the journey being quite traumatic as I tried to cope with driving on the other side of the road. Verdasco was three or four years older and he won 6-1, 6-3, but towards the end Andy was starting to get the hang of his pace of shot. I was thinking "Wow, this is it, the next level!" And then, as I was sitting in the bar afterwards, one of the much older players said "Do you mind if I sit with you?" He started to talk to me about the dangers of the tour, things Andy would have to look out for, match-fixers and people offering vitamins that might not be vitamins. I remember thinking "Oh my God, this is going to be a completely different ride to the junior circuit!"

Matt Little (fitness trainer): Both Rafa [Nadal] and Roger [Federer] had lost in the opening rounds, which put a really palpable pressure on Andy. By the time he reached the Verdasco match, I think he was very much feeling that pressure from the public.

Judy: Before the quarter-final I met Sir Alex Ferguson in the player restaurant for tea. Chats with Sir Alex were like gold dust, and he's been a huge source of advice to me and Andy since 2005. I walked him down to Centre Court and of course we were followed almost immediately by fans and photographers. One guy was walking backwards while facing us with the biggest video camera I ever saw. He said "Sir Alex, a few words for the Spanish media?" Sir Alex says "Yes, of course. Adios amigo." Then he turns to me and says "It's very important to have two words in every language that all mean the same thing."

Green: Verdasco started like a train, hitting the ball so big. I didn't think Andy was gonna lose but I was thinking we needed something. Then Andy hit a running pass on quite a long point and it changed the vibe of the match. From then on, he was on fire.

Judy: Verdasco is so dangerous, but if you hang with him, get him to a point where he starts to lose concentration or get annoyed with himself, it's always possible to turn things around. And Andy knew that. Still, for a while it looked like "Here we go again."

Wednesday, June 5: After a five-set epic over Verdasco, Murray faces surprise semi-finalist and No 24 seed Jerzy Janowicz for a place in the final.

Dani Vallverdu (assistant coach): The rain-break during the Janowicz semi-final was funny. It was one set all and Andy is freaking out because they're going to close the roof. This guy's playing well, serving bombs, so Andy was very concerned. And then they both go to have a shower, and Andy comes out and says, "He's just singing away in there! I think we're gonna be okay."

Lendl (asked if he remembered the story about Janowicz singing during the rain-break): It may surprise you but I don't follow guys into the shower.

Green: After the semi-final, Dan Bloxham [head coach at the All England Club] brought some wine down to where the gym was underneath the stadium. Ricky Gervais came down as well. Andy was very nervous to meet him, because he is a big Office fan - that's classic Andy deadpan humour. Gervais was a good guy, broke the ice really well, and then Janowicz had a glass with us as well. It was a really nice moment.

Sunday, June 9: Through to his second final at Wimbledon, defending champion Novak Djokovic awaits with the Serbian having won the last four Grand Slams titles and defeating Murray in the Australian Open final in January that year

Smith: On the morning of the final, I remember meeting Judy for breakfast in Wimbledon village, so early that it wasn't even busy yet. There was a real buzz - maybe a bit more expectation than against Roger the previous year, and nervousness because of that.

Judy: Before the final, I was sitting on the balcony of the player restaurant by myself. I had a cup of tea and lemon iced doughnut. I had one on the first day for Andy's first match, and I kept doing the same thing every match-day, like a superstition. I didn't really want one for the final, because I was so nervous. But I didn't want to break the superstition just in case. And I got a text from one of my friends saying, "How's your doughnut?" It turned out they were watching BBC TV in Glasgow and one of those drone things had picked me up on the balcony. I thought, "There's no privacy anywhere." Anyway, it worked.

Stewart: When you're driving in on the A3, there are certain pinch points where everybody slows down. As we all do, you look around and see what's going past you and stuff. We were used to people double-taking when they saw Andy. But on the morning of the final, I remember that one car came back alongside five or ten minutes later. They had written "Come on Andy!" on an A4 pad of paper and were holding it up against the window.

Little: The pre match warm-up was quite funny because Novak's team had gotten down to the warm-up area before us. There was no space for Andy out there, so I ended up warming him up in this really tight corridor outside the gym. I always throw balls for Andy to react to, and because I was so nervous, I was throwing them all over the place, which wasn't lost on him.

Vallverdu: The tactic was to make Novak go for his shots. He needed to feel that, if he just rallied, Andy would punish him. If you look at the error count for Novak, it's probably higher than his average that day. If you don't increase Novak's error count, you're in trouble. Andy stuck to the plan. He served brilliantly, and returned brilliantly too. Almost every time he was able to get his racket on the ball, he was putting it back in play.

Green: Early in the match, Andy started going "My shoes are wrong, I need a new pair!" He was hysterical, going bananas.

Bender: The thing with Andy, he can just forget stuff, not pack things. This wasn't like a one-off. Most of the time, the rest of the team would have everything - extra kit, often because he would say "Oh gosh, I forgot this." In this case, I think it was orthotics rather than shoes.

Stewart: There'd been a lot of chat about how slippery the courts were that year. Several players fell and injured themselves. Anyway, Dani picked up that Andy wasn't happy about his shoes, and word got passed back that he didn't have a spare pair. I think it was maybe 2-1 in the first set. I had the car-keys in my pocket, and I ran back - proper sprinting - to the grassy car-park at the back of Aorangi, and then buzzed out onto the A3. At Andy's house, I didn't even get out of the car, or go into the drive. We had rung ahead, and someone threw the shoes over the wall. I made it back to Centre Court at 3-2 in the second set, and if you put that into Google Maps, it's theoretically impossible. Amazingly, I didn't get a speeding ticket. I remember thinking to myself, "Wouldn't this be a great story if he won and it was all down to the shoes?" But do you know what? He put them down by the umpire's chair, and never even put them on.

Bender: In the seven years I spent with Andy, there was always the sense of uncertainty. Is there something missing from the kitbag? Is he cramping? Does he want electrolyte? In that team environment courtside, you have very heightened senses. He's one of those guys who gets his competitiveness from being in the trenches. He wants to rage against someone or something to get him in the red zone. Whether it's screaming "I haven't got my f---king shoes" or "I haven't got my orthotics", it's definitely a process to raise his intensity. He would create chaos in the team to achieve it, like John McEnroe ranting at the chair umpire. When I stopped working with him in 2019, my blood pressure dropped by about 30 per cent.

Vallverdu: I think Andy was calmer that year, he was controlling his ups and downs. Lendl helped him with that, and also with the clearness of the game-plan. Andy was going after his serve and forehand, and sticking to that even when things were not going well. There were tricky moments against Novak, moments when he could have reverted back to being more defensive. He didn't, which was the key.

Judy: I don't remember much about the final. I do remember removing myself from the player's box, sitting three or four rows further back. That player's box is an uncomfortable place to be because it's mixed. You're sitting there with your own friends and family and Andy's team, but also the supporters of your opponent. Having done it the year before and hated it, I also knew you if move yourself back you're not in the front line for the photographers.

Green: That last game was insane. If Andy had lost it, and Novak had broken back to 5-5, it would have got very interesting, Novak was saving all these match points, and he was smiling. It's not a good sign when Novak starts to smile. But I remember that when Novak had a break point, Andy had this short forehand, and he hit it cross-court at a sharp angle for a clean winner. It was a very difficult shot because he was close to the net, so he had to get the ball up and down quickly, but he went after it with total commitment. I have a clear memory of thinking, "He's got this." And then he wrapped it up two or three points later.

Judy: I usually remember big points and opportunities, but in this instance I don't' remember anything about the final till 40-0 in the last game. I was sitting muttering to myself, "Just one serve, Andy! Bash it! Smash it!" My teeth were gritted. I could hear and feel my heart banging away. I was surprised no-one else could hear it. Then it was deuce. Novak got a net-cord, and it was break point. I wouldn't tell you what I said, because you couldn't print it. But inside I was saying "Please don't let this happen."

Vallverdu: That last game was the first time ever - and probably the only time - I felt Ivan nervous. And what gave it away is that he was not speaking for 15 minutes, which is very unlike him. Usually, he talks to you the whole match. I mean, literally every point he will say something. But he was completely silent.

Judy: During the match there was a Buster Bloodvessel lookalike sitting near me in the stand. He would stretch across the aisle and give it the fist-pump whenever Novak won a point, shout whatever they say in Serbian. I could see him out of corner of my eye. I was thinking "I've got enough stress to deal with, I don't need that football mentality as well." I never looked at him, never blinked or wavered, but when Andy won he was right across the aisle to say congrats. That's the thing about sport, you can say what you want while it's going on, but you shake hands afterwards. Still, I was worried that he was gonna punch me at first.

Andrew Castle (commentator): When Andy finally closed it out, Tim Henman - who was sitting next to me in the cramped BBC commentary box - jumped up and put his arms in the air. The problem was, his elbow whacked me in the temple as he did so. I had a bump for days. There I was, trying to find the perfect line for this great moment of sporting history, and really we're all just fortunate that I didn't say "Aww, f---!"

Judy: The first thing Andy did after Novak's backhand hit the net was turn around and look at the press pack. Which was quite interesting because he had had, certainly in the early years, a really rough time with the media. He was the only one after Tim and Greg [Rusedski], so everything was on him. I don't know for sure, but I suspect he was thinking "There you go, you can stop asking me when I'm going to win Wimbledon."

Bender: Andy came with the Pat Cash celebration, running up to the player's box to hug everyone. It was just absolutely mad, total pandemonium.

Judy: Because I was standing so far back, I didn't go to join in. People were saying "Go down, go down." The reason I didn't is that I had been blasted for so many years for being a pushy parent. I thought "I'll just get it in the neck again." Andy turned around and started heading back to the court, and the crowd shouted "What about your mum?" I thought "Okay, I'll go down." When he hugged me, that's when Dijana Djokovic [Novak's mother] came out to shake hands and say congrats. That was such a lovely moment. We had known each other since the boys were 11. Many times when Novak had beaten Andy, I had sought her out to say congrats.

Jamie: I watched the final on a laptop in Stuttgart with my wife. We were going there to play the tournament the following week. It was quite a weird situation, and the stream wasn't even that good. Of course, it would have been great to be there to see him, but the reality was, it definitely wasn't a sure thing. He was playing Novak, he had lost a bunch of finals to that point. I was just glad that he won. I didn't really care that I missed it.

Eleanor Preston (Wimbledon interview manager): I happened to pass the warm-up area underneath the stadium about five minutes after the presentation ceremony. Andy was sitting there, completely alone, in his sweaty whites with his racket-bag next to him. And he was just staring at the floor, expressionlessly. Processing, I would say.

Green: In the locker-room there was champagne going everywhere. Everyone was pumped and laughing. For some reason I took a picture of the trophy with Andy's dirty socks and ankle braces. Andy was very tired but relieved, happy and confused in equal measure, trying to figure out what he had done. Those two actors, Gerard Butler and Bradley Cooper, came down and said "Well done." There were famous pictures of them in the Royal Box during the match, they were so into it. You know what these guys are like, they go towards the winner. And what with Gerard having a Scottish connection, he was an Andy guy. Until he became a Novak guy a couple of years later!

Judy: As soon as I had watched the trophy ceremony, I had to go into organisational mode. To get wristbands for all Andy's friends and family so that they could go up to the competitors' lawn to celebrate. To get champagne and glasses. To work out who was going to the Champions' Dinner, because it's not as if we were turning up to watch Andy with our ballgowns at the ready.

Green: I do remember being up on the lawn and David Cameron was walking across the bridge from the members' area on his way out of the grounds. I'd had a few glasses and I yelled "Thanks for coming, Dave!" Then I was like "Oh, f---, I just called the Prime Minister Dave". His security people weren't too happy, but he was fine, he just smiled. Everyone was very relaxed, very happy. It might seem a bit indulgent to say it, but I felt like there was a really good mood across London for the next 24 hours.

Judy: We had two tables at the Champions Dinner. You go down to the locker-rooms and they've been transformed into an Aladdin's cave. For the men, it's tuxedos, shoes and grooming. For the women, it's wall-to-wall gowns and pashminas, bags, stylists and make up. Not only for you, but for whoever is gonna come with you. I feel like I didn't relax at all until we got to dinner. It was very late and everyone was starving. Andy's media had taken four hours, we were waiting for him, and the Wimbledon restaurants had closed so there was no food. We got to the Savoy and we were in a little holding room with Marion Bartoli. I remember joking to Dr Bartoli, "You and me on the first dance." I didn't realise that it wasn't actually a ball anymore. I'd grown up loving the first dance. But it was just a dinner. I think Andy was really relieved he didn't have to do it.

Bartoli: Andy had so much press to do, he was exhausted. He arrived at 11:30pm-ish, we started quite late. I had my Louboutins, 16cm heels, and I'd been standing for like three hours waiting for him. My feet were so painful, especially with five blisters from my final. My foot was all taped up. But I wore boots so nobody could see that I was wearing socks. By the time he arrived, I could barely walk.

Little: After the match, actually it was quite strange, because we barely saw Andy. He came into the locker room, we said a quick congratulations, and then he disappeared off, to be photographed with the trophy, do the media stuff, get his suit fitted. He didn't sit on the table with us either at the dinner, he sat at the champions' table. I just remember going into Wimbledon the following morning to pick up all our stuff and I finally saw him sitting there on the lawn with the trophy in between some more media stuff that he was doing. I don't remember the conversation, but I remember the look on his face. I'd never seen him so content.

Bender: There's still a real brotherhood of that time. When you go through something quite exceptional, it keeps a bond between people. But I do remember that Andy's back didn't last much beyond Wimbledon. As soon as he got on the hard courts, it seized up again, and he went under the knife for a discectomy in September.

Judy: The next year, when we went back to Wimbledon, I thought "Right, here we go, have a lemon doughnut and a cup of tea and hope that the same thing happens again." And guess what? They'd stopped stocking lemon doughnuts.

Simon Briggs (Telegraph tennis correspondent): Usually we reporters try to maintain a sense of impartiality. But in this instance, for the only time in my career, I broke with protocol. At the morning-after press conference, I asked Murray to sign my Wimbledon pass.

Most of my colleagues did the same. Sports hacks tend to be a cynical, unsentimental bunch. But as Murray ended the 77-year wait for a male British champion at Wimbledon, we were caught up in the unfolding sense of history. You could go through an entire career and never see anything quite like July 7, 2013. The pass is still hanging in my study.

results.title: ODI World Cup 2023 Qualifier  | Zimbabwe ने Super Six में Oman को हराया, Sean Williams बने Player of The Match, ODI World Cup के Qualifire Round Tournament में जिंबाब्वे रेस में आगे, दो खिलाड़ियों ने यहां ठोकी सेंचुरी | Navabharat (नवभारत)
results.body:
ICC ODI World Cup 2023 के Qualifier Round Tournament के सुपर सिक्स के पहले मैच में गुरुवार, 29 जून को जिंबाब्वे ने ओमान को (ZIM vs OMA) 14 रनों से हरा दिया।

Queens Sports Club, Bulawayo, Zimbabwe के मैदान में खेले गए सुपर सिक्स के इस पहले मुकाबले में ओमान ने टॉस जीता और जिंबाब्वे को पहले बल्लेबाजी के लिए बुलाया। जिंबाब्वे ने पहले बल्लेबाजी करते हुए 7 विकेट पर 50 ओवर में 332 रन बनाए और ओमान को जीत के लिए 333 रनों का टारगेट दिया।

जिंबाब्वे की तरफ से सीन विलियम्स (Sean Williams Super Six Oman vs Zimbabwe) ने 103 गेंदों में धमाकेदार बल्लेबाज़ी करते हुए 14 चौके और 3 छक्कों के साथ कुल 142 रनों की पारी खेली। ओमान की तरफ़ से गेंदबाज़ी में फयाज़ बट (Fayyaz Butt) ने अपने 10 ओवर के स्पेल में 79 रन देकर 4 विकेट चटकाए।

जीत के लिए जिंबाब्वे से मिले 333 रनों के लक्ष्य को चेज़ करने मैदान में उतरी ओमान की टीम टारगेट के करीब पहुंच चुकी थी, लेकिन जिंबाब्वे की धारदार बोलिंग और कसी हुई फील्डिंग के सामने ओमान की रन बनाने की गति में लगाम कस गया। और, ओमान 50 ओवर में 9 विकेट पर 318 रन ही बना सकी और उसे हार का सामना करना पड़ा। ओमान के सलामी बल्लेबाज कश्यप प्रजापति (Kashyap Prajapati Oman) ने 97 गेंदों में 12 चौके और 1 छक्के की मदद से 103 रनों की पारी खेली। लेकिन, उनकी यह लाजवाब पारी ओमान के काम नहीं आई।

Zimbabwe vs Oman सुपर सिक्स मैच में दोनों की Playing 11

जिम्बाब्वे की प्लेइंग इलेवन

Joylord Gumbie (WK), Craig Ervine (Captain), Wesley Madhevere, Sean Williams, Sikandar Raza, Ryan Burl, Wellington Masakadza, Luke Jongwe, Richard Ngarava, Tendai Chatara, Blessing Muzarabani.

ओमान की प्लेइंग इलेवन

Kashyap Prajapati, Jatinder Singh, Aqib Ilyas, Zeeshan Maqsood (Captain), Mohammad Nadeem, Shoaib Khan, Ayaan Khan, Naseem Khushi (WK), Fayyaz Butt, Kaleemullah, Bilal Khan.

results.title: Record number of WA government agencies at risk of fraud
results.body:
'Stark': Record number of government agencies rebuked over corruption risk, poor data and money controlsJosh ZimmermanThe West AustralianFri, 30 June 2023 2:19PMCommentsCommentsPremiumEmail Josh Zimmerman

A record number of WA government agencies have been hauled over the coals for significant financial and security weaknesses that leave them exposed to corruption, data breaches and overpayment of staff.

In a report released Friday, Auditor General Caroline Spencer highlighted the ongoing failure by government entities to properly account for the money and sensitive data entrusted to them by the public.

results.title: You're going to want this limited-edition Pixel Fold set but you can't buy it
results.body: We may earn a commission if you make a purchase from the links on this page. Google has produced a limited-edition version of the Pixel Fold that celebrates the 50th-anniversary of Hip Hop. Google decided to produce only 400 limited-edition Pixel Fold units in Obsidian with metallic accents added to the sides and the camera bar. The latter also sports a special 50th anniversary logo. And what's cool is that the suitcase the phone is packaged in is a record player made by Victrola.

results.title: Return of the dreaded blue press room
results.body:
HAPPY MEDIUM: This weekend we'll be exactly halfway through the year. In the final six months of 2022 we had three prime ministers ... three chancellors ... and 37 ministerial resignations outside a reshuffle (h/t the IFG). Since January 1 we've had one, one and four. Boring! But haters of stability need not fear. The election may be less than a year away.

Good Friday morning. This is Dan Bloom. Rosa Prince returns on Monday.

THERE'S NO PLACE LIKE HOME: As if we've all woken up sweating back in the COVID nightmare, Prime Minister Rishi Sunak will return to 9 Downing Street's blue-hued press room at noon flanked by two senior medics to tell a nervous nation the NHS can -- we promise -- turn things around.

OK, calm down: It's only the long, long-awaited 15-year NHS workforce plan.

**A message from Palantir: Whether rolling out the COVID vaccine, cutting NHS waiting lists, accelerating cancer care, resettling Ukrainian refugees, enabling Royal Navy vessels to spend longer at sea or leading in AI, at Palantir UK we're proud that our software is helping the Government solve some of the UK's most important challenges.**

Wall-to-wall: Health Secretary Steve Barclay is on the Today program at 8.10 a.m. and Labour's Shadow Health Secretary Wes Streeting is also doing a broadcast round. Rishi Sunak is visiting a hospital in the east of England (pics but no pool clip), followed by the presser then a weekend at Chequers. Barclay is likely to give a follow-on statement to the Commons on Monday.

Spin all about it: After a 5,913-word press release with 43 (!) supportive quotes -- but not all questions answered -- the 130-page document should be published this morning from about 9 a.m. Barclay's op-ed in the Telegraph (splash here) calls it the "most radical" reform since the NHS was founded, 75 years ago next week. NHS England Chief Executive Amanda Pritchard in the Mail calls it a "once-in-a-generation opportunity."

Getting the band back together: The press conference is due to feature Pritchard and NHS England Medical Director Stephen Powis, both of whom graced the £2.6 million blue room in the COVID days.

PLAN IN BRIEF: £2.4 billion over five years ... medical school training places doubled to 15,000 a year by 2031 ... 24,000 more nurse and midwife training places by 2031 ... 60,000 doctors and 170,000 more nurses by 2037 ... a consultation on cutting medical degrees from five years to four ... 16 percent of training places offered through apprenticeships by 2028 ... and letting student nurses start work when they graduate in May, rather than having to wait until September.

BIGGEST NUMBER: The Mirror's Martin Bagot hears that the entire workforce in NHS England will expand from 1.4 million to 2.2 million by the end of the 15-year plan.

Black hole: The NHS also claims the plan aims to cut the agency staffing bill by £10 billion between 2030/31 and 2036/37. There are now 112,000 vacancies which would reach 360,000 by 2037 without action.

The bad numbers: Labour circulated a background briefing with the grimmest waiting list figures, including the 520,000 who waited more than four hours at A&E in May.

DEVIL'S IN THE DETAIL: Wonks will pore over the document to see if it answers key questions about funding and timescales. For example, the release says the number of medical school places will rise by "almost a third" by 2028 ... but double by 2031. That means most of the growth is only at the end of this decade.

GETTING IN EARLY: Labour's Wes Streeting said "they should have done this a decade ago" ... the Royal College of Nursing says the key will be the amount and length of funding ... Unison says pay review bodies must be fixed.

Not impressed either: The Health Foundation said "optimistic assumptions" about improving productivity "will be a pipedream without significant investment." It added: "The disappointing lack of detail made available around the announcement makes it impossible to comment on the substance."

LONG ROAD: This plan, promised "shortly" in January, was at one point expected in the week of the March budget. The Times splash says officials "have been locked in talks with a sceptical Treasury," which eventually "backed the key planks."

DEJA VU: The Express splashes "Rishi's radical plan to fix NHS once and for all." But this is not the first plan nor will it be the last. While it's bigger and beefier, we have an aging population, funding strains and pressure that only ever seems to go in one direction.

On repeat: Playbook reporter Noah Keate trawled for some of the NHS' many past plans. To name only a few, there's ... The COVID backlog plan promising to "grow and support the workforce" and recruit 10,000 nurses from overseas (February 2022) ... the Build Back Better plan promising to "improve workforce planning" (September 2021) ... The NHS Long Term Plan which promised a "comprehensive new workforce implementation plan" (January 2019) ... The planned workforce strategy to 2027 (August 2018) ... The 5-year NHS funding plan with 3.4 percent real-terms rises to mark the NHS' 70th birthday (June 2018) ... and a Five Year Forward View that promised to "commission and expand new health and care roles" (October 2014). Not to mention Andrew Lansley's ill-fated reforms, natch (April 2013).

Good timing: A health committee report says NHS England should break from the rigid "Agenda for Change" pay scale to hire digital specialists -- as some areas lack even the most basic IT equipment.

That'll do it! The public should "get fitter" to protect the NHS, Wales' Health Minister Eluned Morgan has told the BBC.

WHATSAPP, DOCKET? A day after the Rwanda drama, the High Court battle between the government and the COVID inquiry it set up begins at 10.30 a.m.

NoBoJo: Ex-PM Boris Johnson has been the test case, but this fight isn't really about him -- especially as he said he'd hand over his phone messages directly. It's about whether the independent inquiry has the right to demand unredacted messages from a slew of ministers and officials so that the inquiry, not government lawyers, can decide what's relevant.

Which means ... the messages of (among many others) Sunak and Cabinet Secretary Simon Case, whose chummy WhatsApp style in former Health Secretary Matt Hancock's leaked trove already raised many eyebrows. Wonder if they'll be named in court?

Breakfast reading: Both sides' skeleton arguments for today's case -- which goes on until mid-Monday -- should be published later today, possibly on the judiciary website. While you wait, the Cabinet Office dumped out 227 pages of documents (here, here, and here) four weeks ago explaining its case and confirming formal requests for WhatsApps had already gone to Case, ex-PM Liz Truss and others.

PANNICK IN THE COURTS OF LONDON: Both Johnson and his ex-aide Henry Cook -- the other subject of a "test case" request by the inquiry -- will also have legal representation in court. Johnson's is David Pannick, the peer who represented him at great public cost in the Partygate committee hearings. Website The Lawyer, which broke the news, adds "treasury devil" James Eadie will spar for the government and Hugo Keith for the inquiry.

HENLEY NON-GRATA: A spectacular row has erupted in Tory safe seat Henley, where the Conservative Party board "abandoned" the selection on Thursday due to what it called "breaches of the parliamentary candidate selection process." News emerged in an e-mail leaked to Michael Crick and key details were broken by the Express' David Maddox.

What the heck's going on? A local activist told Playbook there was "outrage" among members after some hopefuls were "weirdly absent" from the longlist that was confirmed privately in recent days. The activist claimed "there was a staggering amount of anger and bewilderment" and some raised concerns over how the process was run. Officially the reason for halting the process was the breach of confidentiality after details leaked out.

Famous names: Among the people who did make the list so far, two people confirm, was an activist by the name of William Hall -- who by coincidence is the son of Tony Hall, the former Director General of the BBC. Ex-Olympic rower James Cracknell was also going for the seat, and is reported by Maddox to be among those who complained to CCHQ.

Whither Boris? Long tipped for the "chicken run" before he quit parliament, Boris Johnson's team insist he has nothing to do with all this and has no plans to run in Henley. Tory chiefs are confident that he can't run anywhere anyway -- because he's not on the party's approved candidates list.

What happens now? It's all up in the air with no timetable yet to restart. Expect this one to run and run ...

MEANWHILE IN LONDON: The Cabinet Office will not investigate the claim that dropped-out Tory mayoral hopeful Daniel Korski groped TV producer Daisy Goodwin's breast, she tells the Times. She says officials have confirmed she'll have to either do nothing or go to police, as Korski (who denies her allegation) no longer works for the government.

Brick wall: Excluded mayoral candidate Samuel Kasumu has written to Tory Chairman Greg Hands urging him to reopen the London selection process to avoid the impression that "politics trumps any semblance of fairness and humanity." Hands is refusing.

LOOSE LIPS: With all that warm white wine at summer parties, reshuffle speculation season is in full flow. The Express' David Maddox reports Home Secretary Suella Braverman is "set for the chop in a bloodbath," but LBC's Ben Kentish hears Sunak is planning a smaller government jiggle before summer recess and Cabinet changes only later.

Double-booked: Sunak needn't bother calling Liz Truss -- she's planning to launch her new outfit "The Growth Commission" next month, Katy Balls writes in her Times column.

MEANWHILE IN LABOUR: It's a-OK for Keir Starmer to abandon many of his 10 pledges because he said made them while campaigning to become Labour leader -- not PM, one of his most loyal allies has told my colleagues Ailbhe Rea and Aggie Chambre.

Pledges, schmedges: Starmer's well-rehearsed line is that he's had to "adapt" to a changed world since he made his vows to Labour members in 2020. But while she mentions that context too, Jenny Chapman tells today's Westminster Insider: "I think what you're seeing now is his real politics. There was an understanding of the best issues to talk about if you want to become leader of the Labour Party." She adds the "essay question is very different" when you're asking to lead "an entire country."

Didn't get the memo: Jeremy Corbyn's ex-policy chief Andrew Fisher retorts "it shows a complete contempt for the membership." It's part of Ailbhe and Aggie's second half of their ace Starmer profile, out today. Listen here.

MAIL'S BÊTE NOIRE: Just Stop Oil backer and Labour donor Dale Vince has compared climate skeptics to Holocaust deniers in a chat with the Mail.

REMINDER: The watchdog letter on Sue Gray becoming Keir Starmer's chief of staff is thought to have been ready for a couple of days, but it depends on Gray formally confirming she'll begin the job, which might be the source of the hold-up.

**Take your foot off the gas and stop chasing the latest on U.K. climate policy - we'll bring it to your inbox. Try POLITICO Pro Energy & Climate UK, our new policy monitoring service tracking climate policy in Westminster and beyond, today.**

NEWS JUST IN: U.K. GDP grew by 0.1 percent in the first three months of 2023, ONS figures released in the last few minutes show -- the same as the previous quarter. Hardly cork-popping time in Downing Street.

RWANDA FALLOUT: The Court of Appeal blow to Sunak's migrant deportations plan splashes the Guardian and the Mail, while the Independent splash asks: "Was this the day the Tories lost the election?"

So what now? Appeal court judges will decide "on papers" whether to accept a referral to the Supreme Court. Immigration barrister Colin Yeo tells Playbook "it's obviously going to the Supreme Court," with the appeal court more likely than usual to refer because it was divided 2-1. The Telegraph hears Sunak is "confident" he can win while "senior legal sources" tell the Times team the case could be heard within six weeks. (Yeo thinks it'll be "months.")

Not good enough: Tory rumblings have picked up steam -- the Mail spread's headline is "Time to quit Euro human rights court." The Times' Brussels editor Bruno Waterfield also says the EU is facing calls from eight of its member countries to follow Britain's lead with a Rwanda-style scheme.

On the subject of Brussels: Hungary and Poland took a stand against a recent EU migration deal during Thursday's EU summit, blocking any EU leaders' statement on the issue. Leaders are back at it today. My colleagues have the details here.

Hands down: Not one person put up their hand on Question Time in Exeter when asked if they back sending people to Rwanda. Here's the clip.

MORE WATER WOE: The Guardian airs concerns Thames Water could delay its annual accounts after it refused to say when they will be published.

LORDS OF THE INTERNET: The Online Safety Bill is back in the Lords on Tuesday and the government has tried to head off a revolt by announcing a string of amendments. One forcing age verification on adult websites could, the Telegraph says, make punters give face scans. Labour claims ministers are been dragged "kicking and screaming."

WHAT A COUP: Defense editors all have more gear on a line from a Sun story from Monday -- that head of the army Patrick Sanders is expected to step down. His allies tell the Telegraph he is being forced out after criticizing planned cuts to troop numbers, with one telling the Guardian Defense Secretary Ben Wallace "didn't like that." The Mail's Mark Nicol suggests a fallout with his armed forces boss Tony Radakin is to blame. Wallace insisted on Thursday "there's no conspiracy."

SLAPP DEBATE: Ex-Minister David Davis has used parliamentary privilege to air detailed claims about Mohamed Amersi, a donor to the Conservative Party. In Thursday's debate about "strategic litigation against public participation" Davis alleged: "What was it that Mr Amersi wanted to conceal with his SLAPPS? In a word, the truth." The full Hansard record is here.

DISUNITED KINGDOM: Aberconwy MP Robin Millar resigned as Wales Office PPS to vote against updates to sex education in Northern Ireland. ITV News has the write-up.

WRIST-SLAP: TV host Lee Anderson faces a ticking-off from the Sergeant-at-Arms after recording a plug for his show on the parliamentary estate -- where he works his other job as an MP, the Mirror's John Stevens reports.

HOUSING WOE: Nationwide's house price data is due out any moment, and HMRC releases house sale statistics at 9.30 a.m.

TICK TOCK: MPs have told the Premier League and EFL to "get their act together soon" on agreeing to share more revenue with lower-league clubs -- or risk the government imposing one.

PRESS PAWS: Schools Minister Nick Gibb has poured cold water on disputed "child who identifies as a cat" stories, telling the Telegraph's Chopper's Politics podcast: "I don't think there are any children in our schools that are identifying as animals."

WASTE OF TIME: Household recycling rates have not improved for more than a decade, says the National Audit Office (via the Mirror).

PUB QUIZ: What do the U.K., Republic of Congo, Haiti, Liberia and Montenegro have in common? They have all slipped down the 2023 rankings in the annual global index of workers' rights produced by trade unions, who blame the minimum service levels bill.

RED TOP LETTER DAY: The Mirror splashes on a full-page handwritten letter from a seven-year-old calling for free school meals for all primary pupils: "If you don't have food your brain won't learn."

TANKS ON OUR LAWN: My colleague Cristina Gallardo has a feature looking at the U.K.'s quiet move towards defense co-operation with the EU -- and why Brexiteers aren't happy about it.

Here's some harmony: Some 61 percent of people now believe the Northern Ireland protocol -- with Sunak's Windsor Framework attached -- is a good thing for the region, says polling by Queen's University Belfast (via PA).

IN FROM THE COLD: Britain's joint intelligence committee produced twice as much material in one month as a previous year -- but still didn't foresee the speed of the Taliban takeover, its recently retired Chair Simon Gass has told The Economist.

ILL HEALTH: The government has rejected the Women and Equalities Committee's plea to set a target to racial disparities in maternal deaths -- its full response is here.

HOUSE OF LORDS: Sits from 10 a.m. with debates on fighting fraud and U.K. defense policy.

JAIL TIME: HMP Fosse Way in Leicester is opened by Justice Secretary Alex Chalk today to house 1,715 prisoners, notching the total up to 5,000 of 20,000 prison places promised by the government.

BACK TO HIS HOMELAND: Leveling-Up Secretary Michael Gove is speaking to 32 council leaders at the Convention of Scottish Local Authorities at 11.30 a.m.

I'M STILL SITTING: French President Emmanuel Macron attended an Elton John gig as riots unfolded over the killing of a 17-year-old, the Times reports. A French policeman was charged with homicide (via the BBC).

PAIN AND GLORY: POLITICO's print cover story this week explores how Spain went in a few short decades from sending gay people to work camps, to allowing gay adoption and making it easier for people to change their legal gender -- plus how it could go into reverse. Read it here, from Aitor Hernández-Morales.

UP IN THE AIR: The Chinese spy balloon which flew over the U.S. earlier this year did not collect information as it traveled across the country, the Pentagon confirmed. Reuters has the details.

RETURN TO IRAQ: The Mirror's Chris Hughes -- who was in Fallujah when U.S. forces killed more than a dozen unarmed Iraqi students, sparking a bloody nationwide insurgence -- has returned to the city 20 years later seeing how it has changed.

**A message from Palantir: Palantir software was first used in the NHS during COVID, helping to ensure ventilators and PPE were sent where the data showed they were needed most. It then supported the vaccine rollout, with the Kings Fund describing it as "a key tool in the NHS's biggest ever exercise in operational data integration".  The same software is now being used to reduce waiting lists at hospitals such as Chelsea and Westminster Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, which has seen a 28 percent fall. It is also helping accelerate cancer treatment and reduce paperwork. As a software company, we don't collect or monetise data. We simply provide tools that help customers organise and understand their own information. Those tools are built so that access to data, including for what purpose and for how long, is dictated entirely by the customer. **

Health Secretary Steve Barclay broadcast round: GB News (6.50 a.m.) ... Sky News (7.20 a.m.) ... Today program (8.10 a.m.) ... GMB (8.25 a.m.).

Shadow Health Secretary Wes Streeting broadcast round: GMB (6.40 a.m.) ... GB News (7.05 a.m.) ... Times Radio (7.20 a.m.) ... Today program (7.40 a.m.) ... LBC (8.05 a.m.) ... Sky News (8.20 a.m.).

Financial Times: Record withdrawals from banks as British households tap into savings.

i: Mortgage deals hiked again -- as big six banks raise their prices.

The Guardian: Tories risk bitter legal feud after Rwanda policy is ruled unlawful.

EU Confidential: The team discuss potential Wagner forces in Belarus with Lithuanian President Gitanas Nausėda and Scotland's future EU relationship with First Minister Humza Yousaf.

Westminster Insider: POLITICO's Ailbhe Rea and Agnes Chambre conclude their two-part profile of Labour leader Keir Starmer.

Plus 6 of the other best political podcasts to listen to this weekend:

Leading: Alastair Campbell and Rory Stewart are in conversation with former Prime Minister John Major about the Gulf War, Black Wednesday and populism.

TOO THIRSTY! The Sports and Social was forced to close early due to overcrowding on Thursday night and Lords authorities are now investigating, tweets the Spectator's James Heale.

FRIDAY FILM CLUB: A plethora of historical films are on TV this weekend to take your mind off politics -- Second World War dramas In Which We Serve (made with the assistance of the Ministry of Information) and Escape to Athena are on BBC Two on Saturday at 1.15 p.m. and 3.05 p.m. respectively ... and the 2018 film Mary Queen of Scots is on BBC One on Sunday at 10.30 p.m.

NOAH'S CULTURE FIX: Verdi's Il trovatore closes at the Royal Opera House on Sunday at 3 p.m. -- a 24-minute walk from Westminster.

NOW READ: The center-right on both sides of the Atlantic has imploded and allowed right-wing populism to flourish, argues an interesting long-read from Jonathan Martin in POLITICO.

results.title: World's First Flying Car Soon To Take Off In US As The Government Grants Certification; Everything You Should Know
results.body:
The flying car developed by Alef Aeronautics is based in San Mateo, California.

Alef Aeronautics has obtained official permission to operate its flying car from the US government. The car manufacturer recently announced the acquisition of a Special Airworthiness Certification from the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), as confirmed by Aero Law Center, a renowned aviation law firm. This significant milestone marks the first-ever certification granted to a vehicle of this kind in the United States.

SEE ALSO: From Unfold To Unhappy: Google Pixel Fold Users Face Screen Snags Within 24 Hours Of Buying

Alef Aeronautics issued a statement acknowledging that the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is currently engaged in developing policies regarding electrical vertical takeoff and landing (eVTOL) vehicles. The company also noted the FAA's efforts in establishing regulations for the interaction between eVTOLs and ground infrastructure.

According to a report from Fox News, the flying car developed by Alef Aeronautics is based in San Mateo, California. This innovative vehicle operates solely on electricity and has the capacity to accommodate one or two individuals. With a price tag of approximately $300,000, the car offers the unique capability of flying over congested traffic and bypassing road accidents.

In October 2022, Alef Aeronautics made a significant announcement by unveiling a full-sized sports car, accompanied by two fully functional technology demonstrator cars. Additionally, the company revealed that it had received more than 440 pre-orders for its vehicles, including orders from individual customers as well as corporate consumers. According to reports, Alef Aeronautics has set a target to commence the delivery of flying cars to customers by the end of 2025.

SEE ALSO: Your Instagram And Facebook Feed Is Influenced By AI

As stated on their website, Alef Aeronautics is developing the flying car specifically for operation on both urban and rural roads. The vehicle is designed to be compatible with regular parking spaces and can fit inside a standard-sized garage. However, due to its classification as a low-speed vehicle, it is limited to a maximum speed of 25 miles per hour on paved surfaces. Alef emphasizes that the car's primary purpose is to provide flight capabilities for faster routes, assuming that if a driver requires a quicker journey, they would utilize the car's aerial functionality.

Source

results.title: Stanley to host weekend bazaar
results.body:
In collaboration with local groups, the Food & Environmental Hygiene Department will stage a weekend bazaar at Stanley Promenade this Saturday and Sunday.

The bazaar will be open from 11am to 6pm each day. Entry is free.

Comprising various food and shopping stalls, as well as singing, dancing and sports performances, the event will create a festive atmosphere for the public to celebrate the 26th anniversary of Hong Kong's return to the motherland.

results.title: Triumphant return from World Summer Games for Special Olympics athletes
results.body:
Beaming smiles, hugs and cheers greeted Manawatū's contingent of New Zealand Special Olympics athletes when they arrived home from the World Summer Games in Berlin, Germany.

At Palmerston North Airport on Friday, they were greeted by a raucous bunch of supporters, who played the national anthem as the delegation entered the terminal.

The athletes themselves were thrilled too, proudly sporting their medals and ribbons from Berlin.

The Manawatū contingent was made up of swimmer Jesse Williams of Palmerston North, athletics competitor Jamie Davidson from Pahīatua, Palmerston North 3X3 basketballer Hayden Wilson, Levin bocce player Aaron Campbell and Palmerston North's Joshua Ryan, a tenpin bowler.

* Special Olympics athletes off to pinnacle event, World Summer Games in Berlin

* Winter Olympics: Meet the New Zealand team going for gold at Beijing 2022

* Olympic Games: Australia eyes Athens gold haul mark with record 14 won, four to go

They were part of the 61-strong New Zealand team - 39 athletes and 22 coaches or support staff.

Other members of the team from Manawatū were head swim coach Carla L'Huillier, who was attending her second world games, athlete support Olwyn Humphries, who was attending her third world games, and team doctor Nicole Lundon.

Davidson won a silver medal in the 100m and a bronze in the 4X100m relay. He also set a personal best in the javelin.

He said he had enjoyed the event and meeting other athletes, and was keen to emphasise his results had been a team effort.

It was the fourth world games for Ryan and he won a bronze in the tenpin bowling pairs and finished sixth in the singles.

He said he had been nervous before the event and it had been a hard competition, but he felt happy after he won.

Williams won two bronze medals, in the freestyle relay and 50m freestyle, and was fifth in the 25m freestyle.

Nervous before the competition, he had ultimately enjoyed the event. His favourite parts of the trip were winning medals and sightseeing.

Wilson and the basketballers were pipped for bronze at the end of the last game, but he said it was a good competition.

Campbell won gold in bocce, one of five gold medals the NZ team brought home. In total, they won a record 34 medals.

Grant Robertson, Minister for Sport and Recreation, mentioned Campbell while congratulating the team in Parliament.

"Bocce player Aaron Campbell from the mighty Ōtaki electorate enjoying two personal bests, winning New Zealand's first Special Olympics gold medal and travelling overseas for the first time in his life," he said.

Special Olympics offers sporting opportunities for athletes with intellectual disabilities and this four-yearly event was their pinnacle competition.

More than 7000 athletes from 190 different countries attended the event, competing in 26 sports.

results.title: Elon Musk and Mark Zuckerberg Asked to Battle in Colosseum? - TV6 News
results.body:
Okay, this is pretty wild. Apparently, some official from the Italian government contacted Mark Zuckerberg about staging a UFC fight against Elon Musk at the Colosseum in Rome! That's according to TMZ Sports, which has sources claiming both Facebook and Tesla bosses are up for it.

It seems like they're serious too - the report says Zuckerberg was contacted by Italy's Minister of Culture a few days ago. Facebook then told Dana White at UFC headquarters and their people went back to the Italian Ministry. Height discrepancies could render fight negotiations tricky though, especially when it comes to body weight - Musk has approximately 85 pounds on Zuck!

No events have taken place inside Colosseum in hundreds of years but Macca played an exclusive charity show there quite recently-ish (in 2003?) so anything really can happen. Naturally I have absolutely no idea if this is or isn't true makeup for your own mind as you go along folks because WE JUST DON'T KNOW AT THIS POINT on that one.#zoopsia

results.title: Forsyth, Nowak named Pac-12 Tom Hansen Medal recipients
results.body:
The award is given annually to the outstanding senior male and female athlete from each member institution based on a combination of the best performance and achievement in scholarship, sportsmanship and leadership.

Conference medal winners have been named every year since the 1960-61 school year. In 2009, the Pac-12 renamed the award the Tom Hansen Conference Medal in honor of Hansen, who retired at the end of June 2009 after serving 26 years as Pac-10 commissioner.

Football (West Linn, Ore.)- Earned a master's degree in advertising and brand responsibility after completing a bachelor's degree in journalism with a 3.49 GPA. Named a semifinalist for the William V. Campbell Trophy (nicknamed the "Academic Heisman"), awarded to the American college football player with the best combination of academics, community service and on-field performance Three-time All-Pac-12 selection on offensive line (first team in 2022; second team in 2020 and 2021) and FWAA named a second-team All-American ... Allowed just one pressure and zero sacks in 384 pass-blocking opportunities in 2022 leads Oregon blockers with an 85.8 passer rating by PFF, fourth-best among all FBS centers. The Ducks allowed just five sacks, the fewest non-sacks. triple option team since 2015 Helped Oregon become the only FBS offense to finish in the top 17 in both rushing and passing yards. Selected in the 7th round (257th) of the 2023 NFL Draft by the Denver Broncos, one of three finalists for Jason Witten. Collegiate Man of the Year Award ... Member of the Mentoring Program and performed community service through the O Heroes program.

Acrobatics & Tumbling (Howell, NJ)- Degree in human physiology with an average of 3.59 points. Four-time National Collegiate Acrobatics & Tumbling Association (NCATA) Academic Honor Roll (2020-23) Three-time Pac-12 Spring Academic Honor Roll recipient (2021, 2022, 2023) ) 2023 NCATA All-American, helped Oregon to No. 2 national ranking, its best after 2019. Earned NCATA Athlete of the Week for February 2023 after UO's upset of Azusa Pacific Competed in all nine games in 2023 and all 26 games Career of the Year Oregon Student-Athlete Advisory Committee (SAAC) Board Member Participated in Pac-12 Student-Athlete Leadership Team (SALT) conference in May 2023 Worked on the Duck the Stigma program to raise awareness of mental health issues Traveled to Guatemala in 2022 with Courts for Kids, an international service organization that facilitates the construction of sports fields in rural communities around the world.

results.title: Peter Stringer: I feel like I've never worked a day in my life - I do things that I love
results.body:
Now a founder of online fitness platform BODYPLAN and co-owner of F45 gym in The Elysian in Cork, Stringer says the two keys to success he has picked up in his professional career are routine and balance.

"Having been in professional sport, [training] is all about routine and getting things in place so that you know when things should happen, and things tend to run smoothly most of the time," he says.

Nutrition is vital for Stringer too. When you eat a balanced diet, he says, and "fuel your body with the right types of foods, then you'll be able to get the rewards from a training perspective".

I like to keep my day pretty active. I don't sit at a desk all day, which is a big plus in my eyes coming from professional sport. I like to get up early before the kids wake up and get my training done.

Weight training and running are what I enjoy. I'm still able to run, my knees and ankles are all good, so I'm going to keep doing that as long as I can.

What are your guiltiest pleasures?

I love chocolate and cakes like everybody else, but I have no guilt if I do eat something sweet. I find the easiest approach is to allow yourself [a treat] on a daily basis, but understanding not to overdo it.

What keeps you awake at night?

My three-year-old son. Our day starts at 4.30am when he gets up and decides it's morning time.

How do you relax?

The hour and a half in the gym, even though it's tough and strenuous. Everyone needs that little bit of space to themselves and for me that's it.

What is your favourite smell?

A new car, and there's something about freshly baked bread as well.

When was the last time you cried?

Probably three years ago when my second son -- Oscar -- was born.

Dishonesty. During my career, when you're playing you like to have honest conversations with people. There's nothing worse than someone not speaking their mind and agreeing with you, and then behind your back saying something else about it to somebody else.

What traits do you least like about yourself?

At times, like everybody, I get stressed and bring work home with me. That's probably something that I need to focus on, in terms of keeping things separate and just being in a moment with my family.

What cheers you up if you're having a bad day?

Just being around my two kids and my wife, when they're in a good mood it makes everything else seem irrelevant.

Who would you invite to your dream dinner party?

An all-time favourite of mine is Billy Connolly. I'd also bring Kevin Hart, and maybe Muhammad Ali.

What quote inspires you most and why?

"In any walk of life, whether it's sports or work or school, ultimately if it's not something you're passionate about doing, it's never going to work for you."

I feel like I've never worked a day in my life, I do things that I love doing because it motivates me to do them even more.

You've got to have passion for something you do because otherwise you just won't commit yourself to it and it won't work.

Where is your favourite place in the world?

West Cork. We had a summer house down in Rosscarbery growing up as a kid.

On sunny days, there's just something about going back to that place.

results.title: A soundtrack for the season from rock band that includes former R.E.M. members
results.body:
By STEVEN WINE

The Associated Press

Baseball's anthem "Take Me Out to the Ballgame" was crafted by two Tin Pan Alley songwriters who had never attended a game. By contrast, the tunes on "Grand Salami Time!" come from a band with extensive knowledge of the sport.

The album is the fourth by the Baseball Project, and the group - Scott McCaughey, Steve Wynn, Linda Pitmon, and former R.E.M. members Peter Buck and Mike Mills - mines nostalgia and esoterica to find fresh subject matter for 16 songs.

We're talking inside baseball: A tribute to pitcher Jim Bouton makes a veiled reference to his career record of 64-64. The song "New Oh in Town" salutes Japanese heroes past and present. "Screwball" cleverly merges two subjects as it recalls players who pitched more than a century ago.

Most topics are paired with garage rock that gives Buck a chance to serve up some delightful guitar squall. Also contributing is co-producer Mitch Easter, who worked on R.E.M.'s early albums.

The band finds room for such contemporary clatter as launch angle, exit velocity and WHIP, but the best songs involve a different kind of analytics. The bluesy "Erasable Man" laments the color line, while the acoustic folk of "That's Living" contemplates life's short season.

As on previous albums, a few lyrics could use a sports editor, or any editor. "Eight-hundred-sixty-eight longballs would fly" just isn't singable. But no band bats 1.000.
